•What are mullerian and wolffarian ducts?

•During embryogenesis which part of female and male organs are formed by these glands?

Define and give examples of 

•Gynogenesis

•Hybridogenesis

node.content:
Gyogenesis: 

A form of asexual reproduction related to parthenogenesis is gynogenesis. Here, offspring are produced by the same mechanism as in parthenogenesis, but with the requirement that the egg merely be stimulated by the presence of sperm in order to develop.

Some salamanders of the genus Ambystoma are gynogenetic and appear to have been so for over a million years.

Hybridogenesis is a mode of reproduction of hybrids. Hybridogenetic hybrids (for example AB genome), usually females, during gametogenesis exclude one of parental genomes (A) and produce gametes with unrecombined genome of second parental species (B), instead of containing mixed recombined parental genomes.

This form of reproduction is seen in some live-bearing fish of the genus Poeciliopsis as well as in some of the Pelophylax spp. ("green frogs" or "waterfrogs").

Please see more details at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthenogenesis#Gynogenesis

doubts.content: What is recapitulation theroy

node.content: according to this theory each organism during its embryonal development passes through all stages,through which it's species has evolved or embryo repeat it's ancestry
ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny

In 1886 Ernst Haekel proposed that theembryonic development of an individual organism followed the same path as the evolutionary history of its species. It is also called the biogenetic law or embryological parallelism

The theory basically stated that before they are born, organisms pass through developmental stages that look like adult animals of other species, in roughly the same order that these other species split off during evolution.

doubts.content: how to find whether a compound has pi bond or sigma bond

node.content:
Usually, all bonds between atoms in most organic compounds contain one sigma bond each. If it is a single bond, it contains only sigma bond. Multiple bonds however, contains sigma and pi bonds. Double bonds have one each, and triple have one sigma bond and two pi bonds.
So, 1 single bond= 1 sigma bond
1 double bond= 1sigma + 1 pi bond
1 triple bond= 1sigma + 2 pi bonds

doubts.content:
Please tell me which formula to apply. 
A train of length 400m moving with a speed of 90km/hr crosses a bridge of length l in one minute. The  length l is equal to 
1) 1600m 2) 1500m 3) 1100m 4) 600m

node.content:
Speed = 90 km/hour =90*(1000/3600) m/sec = 25 m/sec

Total distance to be covered = bridge length+train length = L+400 meters

Time = Distance/Speed
 1 min*60  = (L+400) /25

60*25=L+400

1500-400=L

L=1100 m

Speed = 90 km/hour =90*(1000/3600) m/sec = 25 m/sec

Total distance to be covered = bridge length+train length = L+400 meters

Time = Distance/Speed
 1 min*60 (s/min)  = (L+400) m /(25 m/s)

60*25 m=(L+400) m

1500-400=L

L=1100 m

node.content:
A singlet linkage is formed between atoms one of which has complete octet of electrons and is capable of donating electrons to other atoms. So, in phosphorus pentachloride, three of the chlorine atoms are supposed to be attached to the phosphorus atom by covalent linkages whereas the other two chlorine atom are joined to it by singlet linkages.
And in SF6, there will be two covalent and four singlet linkages.

Then why in Griffith's experiment <S pneumonia> R-2(i.e. Rough and non-pathogenic) is totally converted into <S pneumonia>S-3(i.e. Smooth and pathogenic) at the end of experiment, instead of becoming <S pneumonia> R-2 & S-3 hybrid?

Sexual recombination means that half of one parent's genes are combined with half of the other parent's genes in the offspring, which results in gene combination that did not previously exist.

doubts.content: what's centripetal and centrifugal force

node.content:
Centripetal Force:
the force which keeps an object moving with a uniform speed in circular motion. 
it's direction is along the radius of circle from object to the centre.
eg revolving planets, stone tied to a rope and whirling around, etc.

centrifugal force :
it is actually inertia or tendency of a body following the curved path to fly away.
it's direction is opposite to that of centripetal force.
eg cut the rope of a whirling stone.

doubts.content: how PROLACTIN inhibts pregnancy

node.content: prolactin inhibits secretion of GNRH which is responsible for FSH secretion. FSH is responsible for follicular maturation.
and if there is no follicular maturation, there is no ovulation and certainly no fertilization and no pregnancy.

high prolactin levels in women that are not pregnant can prevent the pregnancy from occuring. 
because it can interfere with ovulation thereby causing hormonal imbalance irregular period or no menses, fertility problems, lowering of progesterone level. this all is due to the fact that high prolactin level is a form of natural birth control for lactating moms.

doubts.content: what is the difference between antheridium and antheridiophore

node.content:
An antheridium or antherida (plural: antheridia) is a haploid structure or organ producing and containing male gametes (called antherozoids or sperm). It is present in the gametophyte phase of cryptogams like bryophytes and ferns, and also in the primitive vascular psilotophytes.
In bryophytes, the antheridium is borne on anantheridiophore, a stalk-like structure that carries the antheridium at its apex.

doubts.content: pedigree analysis of autosomal linked diesease

node.content: In humans, controlled crosses cannot be made, so geneticists must resort to scrutinizing family records in the hope that informative matings have been made that can be used to deduce dominance and distinguish autosomal from X-linked inheritance. The investigator traces the history of some variant phenotype back through the history of the family and draws up a family tree, or pedigree, using the standard symbols. The clues in the pedigree have to be interpreted differently depending on whether one of the contrasting phenotypes is a rare disorder or whether both phenotypes of a pair are common morphs of a polymorphism. The genetic disorders of human beings can be dominant or recessive phenotypes and can be either autosomal or X-linked.

node.content: biphenyl itself is not planar, one benzene ring being slightly twisted or canted in relation to the other as a consequence of steric crowding. The resulting chiral conformation, having a dihedral angle of about 45º, equilibrates rapidly with its enantiomer by rotation about the connecting single bond. node.content:
For water the latent heat of heat is 334J/g and the latent heat of vaporization is 2230J/g. Specific heat capacity of water is 4.2J/(gK).

The steam condenses into 100C water, releasing 2230J. 334J of it goes to melting the ice into 0C water. The rest (2230-334 = 1896J) heats up the 0C water to 1896/4.2 = 451C. But water cannot be heated up to 451C! What this means is that not all the steam needs to condense to bring the 0C ice to 100C water. And therefore the water/steam mixture is at 100C. doubts.content: pteridophytes

node.content: Pteridophytes includes the ornamental plants like ferns. The main plant is sporophyte which is differentiated into true root, stem and leaves. They possess well-differentiated vascular tissues.. The sporophytes bear sporangia which produce spores. These spores germinate to form gametophytes. Then gametophytes bear male and female sex organs which later forms respective gametes and then the zygote produces sporophyte and in this way the cycle is repeated.

Pteridophytes or Pteridophyta, in the broad interpretation of the term (or sensu lato), are vascular plants (plants with xylem and phloem) that reproduce and disperse via spores. Because they produce neither flowers nor seeds, they are referred to as cryptogams.

the following reaction occur between S_2 O_3^(2-) and 〖Cr〗_2 O_7^(2-) : 
26H+ + 〖3S〗_2 O_3^(2-) + 〖4Cr〗_2 O_7^(2-) → 6SO_3^(2-) + 8Cr3+ + 13H2O 
Change in oxidation number of 〖Cr〗_2 O_4^(2-) per formula unit is 6 (it is always fixed for 〖Cr〗_2 O_7^(2-)). 
Hence, equivalent weight of K2Cr2O7 = (Molecular weight)/6 
the following reaction occur between S_2 O_3^(2-) and 〖Cr〗_2 O_7^(2-) : 
26H+ + 〖3S〗_2 O_3^(2-) + 〖4Cr〗_2 O_7^(2-) → 6SO_3^(2-) + 8Cr3+ + 13H2O 
Change in oxidation number of 〖Cr〗_2 O_4^(2-) per formula unit is 6 (it is always fixed for 〖Cr〗_2 O_7^(2-)). 
Hence, equivalent weight of K2Cr2O7 = (Molecular weight)/6

doubts.content: what is diff. b/w precision and accuracy

node.content:
Accuracy and Precision:


Accuracy refers to the closeness of a measured value to a standard or known value. For example, if in lab you obtain a weight measurement of 3.2 kg for a given substance, but the actual or known weight is 10 kg, then your measurement is not accurate. In this case, your measurement is not close to the known value.

Precision refers to the closeness of two or more measurements to each other. Using the example above, if you weigh a given substance five times, and get 3.2 kg each time, then your measurement is very precise. Precision is independent of accuracy. You can be very precise but inaccurate, as described above. You can also be accurate but imprecise.

For example, if on average, your measurements for a given substance are close to the known value, but the measurements are far from each other, then you have accuracy without precision.

A good analogy for understanding accuracy and precision is to imagine a basketball player shooting baskets. If the player shoots with accuracy, his aim will always take the ball close to or into the basket. If the player shoots with precision, his aim will always take the ball to the same location which may or may not be close to the basket. A good player will be both accurate and precise by shooting the ball the same way each time and each time making it in the basket.

Source: https://www.ncsu.edu/labwrite/Experimental%20Design/accuracyprecision.htm

doubts.content: What is excretion in plants?

node.content: no definite excretory system or organ is present for removal of wastes in plants. The excretory products which are easily diffusibe are removed by way of diffusion or osmosis. In higher plants waste materials are deposited in various parts of plants such as fruits, in the form of rubber , gum etc. Mostly waste products like carbon dioxide, water vapour and oxygen are removed during respiration in plants. Many plant wastes are stored in cellular vacuole.

doubts.content: the ratio of number of moles of KMno4 and K2Cr2o7 required to oxidise 0.1 mol Sn+2 to Sn+4 in acidic medium

node.content:
2 KMnO4 + 5 Sn2+ + 16 H+ → 5 Sn4 + + 2 Mn2 + + 8 H2O + 2 K+ 
(0.1 mol Sn2+) x (2 mol KMnO4 / 5 mol Sn2+) = 0.04 mol KMnO4  

K2Cr2O7 + 3 Sn2+ + 14 H+ → 3 Sn4+ + 2 Cr3+ + 7 H2O + 2 K+ 
(0.1 mol Sn2+) x (1 mol K2Cr2O7 / 3 mol Sn2+) = 0.03333 mol K2Cr2O7  

(0.04 mol KMnO4) / (0.03333 mol K2Cr2O7) = 0.12 / 0.1 = 1.265

doubts.content: how exactly does terminal force act on a Parachute?

node.content: After about five seconds, you reach a speed where the force of air resistance (pushing you upward) increases so much that it balances the force of gravity (pulling you downward). At that point, there is no net acceleration and you keep on falling at a steady speed called your terminal velocity. Unfortunately, the terminal velocity for a falling person (with arms stretched out in the classic freefall position) is about 55 meters per second (200km/h or 125 mph), which is still plenty fast enough to kill you—especially if you're falling from a plane!

doubts.content: Sir please explain how during complete oxidation of 1 glucose molecule ,it undergoes 2 electron oxidation

node.content:
The types of chemical reactions called oxidation and reduction lie at the heart of respiration. They always occur together - one substance is oxidised as another is reduced. We often use the termredox reactions to describe this.

There are two useful ways of thinking about redox reactions. One is that oxidation is the addition of oxygen and reduction is the removal of oxygen from a substance. For example:

C6H12O6 + 6O2    6CO2 + 6H2O (oxidation of glucose).

However, a more useful definition is in terms of electron transfer:

  • Oxidation is the removal of electrons, e.g. Fe2+    Fe3+ + e-
  • Reduction is the addition of electrons, e.g. Fe3+ + e-     Fe2+

A chemical that supplies electrons is called a reducing agent (or a reductant), and a chemical that accepts electrons is called an oxidising agent (or an oxidant).
Sabira, can you please tell us the relevant video (with time) or question on our website where you have this doubt?
In video 10 at 8:20 of respiration in plants topic

Sabira, the answer is option (2) and not just 2 electrons. So, the answer is 24 electrons oxidation. Please watch the videos of chapter Redox Reactions to understand how oxidation state is calculated. 

An external link which would also be helpful is Oxidation States in Sugar Reactions 

Please remember to provide the context of your doubt such as video no, question no etc. so that it is faster to resolve that.

doubts.content: what is the difference detween heat and temprature?

node.content:
Heat

Heat is the total energy contained by a body, both potential as well as kinetic energy. Potential energy is the stored energy while kinetic energy is the moving energy. It is measured in Joules (J).

Temperature

Temperature is a measure of the kinetic energy of the molecules of an object. It is a number that is related to energy but is not energy itself. It is measured in a number of units such as Kelvin, Fahrenheit and Celsius.

Hope you understand the difference between these two.

Thank You.

We only answer queries based on videos & questions given by us. So, we won't able to provide answer to queries from other reference books in future. 

In the above question: option (4) is right.

Imagine a cube and a charge q at center of that cube. As cube has 6 sides and all sides are symmetric from center, the flux through each side would be total flux divided by 6. The charge would be at a distance half the side of length of cube from center of any face of cube.

The given question is exactly similar to the situation described above. So, option (4) is correct.

node.content:
Answer is (c)

Sol:- Micturition is same as urination. Urination is the act of passing urine which is a reflex phenomenon. As urine accumulates in bladder the stretch receptors are activated that pass the stimulus to the spinal cord. In the absence of stretch receptors the urine would get collected and probably overflow. So, option (b) is not true.

node.content:
Rate of reaction in 1st order reaction is proportional to concentration. This is taught in #2 | Rate Constant 

Therefore, using the formula for 1st reaction taught in #7 | Different Order of Reactions to calculate k, we will get k = 2.303/(t2 - t1) * log{(0.04 * k)/(0.03 * k)}

t2 - t1 = (20 -10) seconds = 10 seconds. Also, k in the log portion will cancel out. 

so, finally we get, k = 2.303/10*log(4/3) 

Now use the formula showing relation between t1/2 & k (t1/2 = 0.693/k ) in #7 | Different Order of Reactions to calculate t1/2
Small correction above: k = 2.303/(t2 - t1) * log{(0.04 * k)/(0.03 * k)} should be k = 2.303/(t2 - t1) * log{(0.04/k)/(0.03/k)}

doubts.content: how to calculate intensity for a given path differnce (  n lemda ) in interfence phenomenon if the maximum intensity (I)  is given.

node.content:
Use the formula for calculating resultant intensity taught in Video #4 to find the relation between intensity of input light and resultant intensity. This is also shown in later part of Video #9 

You will get IR(max) = 4 * Iinput. Please note this question assumes that both the incident light have same intensity. (1)

Now, use the same formula to calculate resultant intensity in terms of input intensity for given path difference. You will need to convert path difference to angle θ. 

You will get: IR = 2Iinput ( 1 +  Cos θ) = 4Iinput Cos 2(θ/2) . Please note that formula used for Cos  θ used is taught in Video #12: Mathematical Tools at 7:00 minute

So, finally you will get: IR = IR(max) Cos 2(θ/2) (Using (1) above)

doubts.content:
Topic:#7 Latent Heat, Thermal Properties of Matter

Duration: 14:08

Description:When sir is writing the expression for 'heat given by steam' why does he add the factor "mC(100-x)" to the latent heat.I mean it should be substracted as it is the heat which is being given out from the latent heat.

One more thing, when ever we find change we do "final-initial" but here sir wrote (100-x) in the expression of heat given by steam.I think it should be (x-100).

Please clarify my doubts.If I am wrong please tell me the correct explaination

node.content:
Please read the explanation given very carefully. Full concentration required. 

Latent heat is heat absorbed/dissipated during phase change. During phase change, there is no change in temperature. So, when latent heat is absorbed/dissipated, there is no specific heat being absorbed/dissipated. 

Specific heat is heat absorbed/dissipated during temperature change. So, when specific heat is absorbed/dissipated, there is no latent heat being absorbed/dissipated.

total heat absorbed/dissipated = heat absorbed/dissipated during phase change + heat absorbed/dissipated during temperature change. 

Now, heat absorbed/dissipated is always assumed to be positive. If heat absorbed is negative, it should be called heat dissipated instead and will become positive as heat dissipated. 

Therefore, in the problem, you have to compute heat dissipated by steam in such a way that it comes out to be positive. If you do (x-100), will it be positive or negative?

The other way you can formulate the above problem is total heat absorbed/dissipated by the steam & ice system is zero.

So, you can do  ΔQice + ΔQsteam = 0 (Here you can do change as final - initial for both temperature change. Also be careful in sign with latent heat of steam. It will be positive when going from water to steam and negative when going from steam to water)

The above equation can also be written as ΔQice = - ΔQsteam which is essentially heat absorbed by ice = heat dissipated by steam.

how can we involve COM concept here? com is for mass their is no centre of charge right??????????????????????

node.content:
This is a special kind of problem where COM can be used to compute dipole moment. COM method can be used for equal and opposite charges where charge and masses are distributed in similar manner. 

The explanation below requires quite a bit of mental gymnastics. So, please pay due attention. 

COM dipole moment situation: Consider total charge Q distributed in space. Now place opposite of total charge (-Q) at a chosen origin as point charge.

Dipole moment of this system(Q and -Q) =  ∫dq * r⃗

Now, COM = ∫(dm * r⃗) ÷ (∫dm) [Center of mass definition in integral form]. Also revise #1 | Definition of Center of Mass at 25 minutes if required. 

Now, as we assumed mass is distributed in similar fashion as charge, we can write COM = (∫dq * r⃗) ÷ (∫dq) 

Given (∫dq)  = Q,

Therefore COM * Q = dipole moment of the above system. Please note that this is a vector as COM is a position vector.

In the problem done by sir, one can imagine the two imaginary dipoles equivalent to given dipole. 

1) +Q on quarter circular ring and -Q (point charge) at center of ring.  

2) -Q on quarter circular ring and +Q (point charge) at center of ring.

Please note that imaginary charges at center of ring cancel out and therefore, the above system of two dipoles is equivalent to dipole given in the problem. 

Each of the imaginary dipoles is equivalent to COM dipole moment situation described above.

Now, you do vector addition (#15 | Vectors: Addition) of dipole moments of the two imaginary dipoles to get answer. If you do the vector addition correctly, you would get the same answer as shown in the solution by sir.

Topic-Solubility Product

Duration- 10:00

Description- Are solubility and concentration same thing.If no then what is the difference?

node.content:
Explained well at wiki page: 

In chemistry, concentration is the abundance of a constituent divided by the total volume of a mixture. Several types of mathematical description can be distinguished: mass concentration, molar concentration, number concentration, and volume concentration. The term concentration can be applied to any kind of chemical mixture, but most frequently it refers to solutes and solvents in solutions. [Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concentration]

So, solubility refers specifically to solute and solvents in solutions. In general, concentration has more generic meaning than solubility. In the context of solubility, concentration has same meaning as that of solubility.

doubts.content:
when double bond is at alpha position then SN1 is not favour.why? 

which bond lenght decreases?

node.content: Conjugation of pi electron and + ve charge is possible at beta position

Two effects make the carbon–halogen bonds of aryl and vinylic halides shorter and stronger: (1) The carbon of either type of halide is sp 2 hybridized, and therefore the electrons of the carbon orbital are closer to the nucleus than those of an sp 3 -hybridized carbon. (2) Resonance of double bond with lone pair in halogen atom makes carbon–halogen bond stronger by giving it double-bond character. 

They are unreactive in S N 1 reactions because alkenyl and phenyl cations are relatively unstable and do not form readily. They are unreactive in S N 2 reactions because the carbon–halogen bond of an alkenyl or phenyl halide is stronger than that of an alkyl halide, and the electrons of the double bond or benzene ring repel the approach of a nucleophile from the back side.

Source: Solomon's organic chemistry

Please note that this rule is applicable in SN1 reactions and not SN2 which was being discussed. In SN2 reaction, the nuclephile will attack the less bulky side as discussed in the rule 1. So, the products for SN2 reaction in this case will be different to what will be in SN1 reaction being discussed now. 

SN1 reaction of Ethyl tert-butyl ether with HBr will give Tert-butyl bromide and Ethanol. 

SN2 reaction of Ethyl tert-butyl ether with HBr will give Tert-butyl alcohol and Ethyl bromide.

doubts.content: what is the criterion for neglecting the H+ ion concentration?

node.content:
Generally, you will find that *comparatively* smaller values are ignored in addition/substraction calculations. Even if those ignored values were included in calculation, there won't be any appreciable difference in the answer obtained. So, ignoring them doesn't matter for answer calculations and allows for easier calculations. 

That's why in this case 10-7 H+ ions of water are considered when H+ ions obtained from acid(HCl here) are comparable and ignored when not comparable.

node.content:
First step: (calculate moles of each reactant without thinking about the ration in which they will react): wahan par moles of Fe calculate kar rahe hai bas..to 1 mole of Fe ka weight le rahe hai..

Second step: (now think about ratio of moles which will react with each other): ab aage 1 mole of Zn 2 mole of Fe se react karega wo deal kiya hai.. 

You can mix the above two steps into one and divide by 112 in this case for Fe. Then you will not need to do second step. Just the minimum of all reactant will be limiting reagent.

But to find the value of product moles, you will need to find number of moles of reactant(step 1) and then multiple by ratio as sir is doing in latter part. So, better to follow two step method as that helps in finding the moles of product easily too.

why there a need to use saffranin

because gram + to coloured h to dikh hi jayenge but jo bacteria nhi dikh rhe h gram- unhe dekhne k liye saffranine use krenge    kya m thk soch rhi hu

kya saffranine ka gram + pr koi effect hoga??

node.content:
There are three possibilities in the beginning: 

i) Gram positive bacteria is present. 

ii) Gram negative bacteria is present.

iii) No bacteria is present.

there are still two possibilities remaining in "without stain" case after ruling out "Gram positive" bacteria.  

1) Gram negative bacteria is present.

2) No bacteria is present.

That's why Safranin is used to rule out case 2) 

Actually both Gram-positive bacteria and Gram-negative bacteria pick up the Safranin, which results in pink colour. Pink colour, however, is unseen on Gram-positive bacteria because of the darker crystal violet stain.

doubts.content: Please help me to find out the breakdown voltage?

node.content:
Better to mention your solution as well or atleast how are you trying to solve. So that it is easier to help. Since you didn't, here are the steps you should be following: 

The solution is based on the idea that given a battery of v volts, the voltages across each capacitor should be less than specified voltages for them. Otherwise, those capacitors will not function properly. 

1. Assuming V volts battery, calculate total Q (using effective capacitance)

2. Now apply Kirchoff's voltage law to all the loops in the diagram. (Hope you can identify the 3 loops). You would need to assume some charge value on one capacitor and calculate charges on other capacitor using total Q from above. 

3. Now, calculate voltage across all capactor now. The condition now is that voltage shouldn't exceed given voltage for each capactior now. 

4. From each of the above 4 conditions, you should get max voltage for the battery. 

5. The minimum among them should be breakdown voltage. 

Now a small trick you can use is based on the observation that ratio of capacitances (in series) is same in both cases. 6/2 = 3/1. So charge on 6 micro farad capacitance is twice that of 3 micro farad capacitance. You will get this from Kirchoff's voltage law as well. 

Please try and see if you can solve this now.

doubts.content: But if 1st sentence says that selection and inbreeding are antagonistic, then where selection exists inbreeding will not be there, and where inbreeding exists selection will not be there right?

node.content:
I dont understand exactly your doubt now. So, giving a small example below. Please go through it carefully. This requires what you would have learnt in 'Principles of Inheritance and variation'. 

Please consider harmful recessive gene 'a' and its dominant allele A (not harmful).

Suppose both parents are 'Aa' genotype. 

Now inbreeding can result into AA, Aa & aa genotype in children. So, harmful recessive gene is exposed in child having 'aa' genotype and this child will diseased. Other genotypes will be healthy. 

The child with 'aa' genotype is likely to be eliminated by natural selection. Likewise, you can think of what will happen in next generation of healthy children.

As told by J K Mishra sir: 

Meiosis occurs in both cases. 

In acellular slime mould plasmodium is diploid structure and frutification takes place during unfavorable condition and meiosis takes place to produce haploid spore. 

In cellular slime mould central myxamoebae engulfs surrounding myxamoebae and nucleus of one fuses with central one and then meiosis takes place in diploid structure to form haploid spores.

node.content:
Sir is right here. 

When one is just looking at flow of charges, the direction along movement of positive charge (or direction opposite to movement of negative charges) is taken to be the direction of the current (defined as such). 

In a simple circuit with a battery and a metal wire resistor, electrons will move from lower potential to higher potential. So, the current direction will be opposite. That's why it comes out that current direction is from positive potential to negative potential. 

So, in this case, sir is defining current by flow of charges and is not considering higher or lower potential.

In this case after calculating the value of B is 10 mol and the given value is 3 sir toh limiting reagent 5 mol of A kyu ni ho skta

Please understand the meaning of limiting reagent again. Read the NCERT section 1.10.1 on Limiting reagent again. If you read that, it says

"Hence, the reactant, which gets consumed first, limits the amount of product formed and is, therefore, called the limiting reagent."  

In the above case, which reactant will get consumed first? In other words, which situation will occur, when reaction proceeds?

1) A is left and B is consumed.

2) B is left and A is consumed. 

A is 5 mol so, it needs 10 mol of B and it gets only 3 mol. 1.5 mol of A will consume 3 mol of B.  3.5 (5 - 1.5) mol of A remains and B is totally consumed. 

So, which one is the limiting reagent?

doubts.content:
Sir, what will be the answers to these questions ?

Are these answers correct ?

1 - 52 H-Bonds

2 - 38 Phosphodiester Bonds

3 - 40 Glycosidic Bonds

node.content:
Right. Please see the explanation below: 

34 Angstrom = 10 base pairs, so 68 Angstrom = 20 base pairs.

a) 40% A=T bps. So, 8 A=T bps as total is 20(from above) and remaining 12 G=C bps. 

A=T Hydrogen bond: A=T bps * 2 = 16,  G=C Hydrogen Bond: G=C bps * 3 = 36. So total Hydrogen bond: 52

b) 20 bps: One strand DNA has 20 nucleotide:

Between adjacent nucleotide, one phosphodiester bond is present. So, 20 adjacent nucleotide will have 19 phosphodiester bonds. 

Equal number of phosphodiester bond on other strand. Therefore, total = 19 * 2 = 38

c) Between sugar and base(part of every nucleotide), there is one glycosidic bond. Therefore, total = 20 * 2 = 40

if AXB=BXA then what is the angle between A and B?

a]pi b]pi/3 c]pi/3 d]pi/4

node.content:
Have you seen the videos of this chapter? 

A X B = AB Sin θ

Then, B X A = AB Sin (360 - θ) = - A B Sin θ

So, for them to be equal, 

sin θ = - sin θ

=> sin θ = 0

therefore, from the given options, θ = π satisfies the above condition

doubts.content: what is difference between mutually inclusive and mutually exclusive events???

node.content:
Mutually exclusive means the events cannot both occur.

Eg: reproduction and growth in multicellular

Mutually inclusive means the events cannot occur independently.

Eg: growth and reproduction are mutually inclusive in unicellular organisms ie. We can not differentiate that a bacteria undergoing fission is growth or reproduction.
inclusive means same & exclusive means different

Is this because of both d and f contraction or only f contraction?

doubts.content:
sir kaise malum chlta h ki graph exponentially decrease krega ya linearly??

jaise yaha pe E vs r ka graph exponentially decrease hora h, to mtlb graph linear nhi hoga wo kaise malum chala??

node.content:
Hello Omkar,

 

Electric field is defined as k q/ r^2 where r is the radius of circle. Now as r square is inversly proportional to E

Hence, the E will increase when r decreases and E will decrease if we increase the radius r. 

From the relation between E and r you can see that E is not linearly dependent on r, but E is exponentially (r has power 2) which means a small change in r will have exponentially effect on E.

This is mathematical statement we conclude from this relation between E and r and the graph between E and r.

 

Hope it helps. Thank You.

These questions consists of two statements each, printed as Statement 1 and Statement 2. While answering these questions you are required to choose any one of the following four responses.

A) If both Statement-1 and Statement-2 are true & Statement-2 is a correct explanation of the Statement-1.

B) If both Statement-1 and Statement-2 are true & Statement-1 is not a correct explaination of the Statement-1.

C) If Statement-1 is true BUT the Statement-2 is false.

D) If Statement-1 and Statement-2 both are false.

1.is least count=accuracy?

2.in relative velocity:is ∆x=accuracy?

3.what is the difference between least count and accuracy?

node.content:
These three terms here all involve collecting/measurring data.

  • Accuracy has to do with how "right" your answer is.
  • Precision has to do with how consistent your answer is.
  • Least Count is the smallest you can measure your answer with the tools at hand.

doubts.content: what is certain and uncertain digit??

node.content:
Hello Anshita,

Certain & Uncertain Digits -- explained!

When a certain measurement of length is taken by a scale of least count 0.01 cm, the result is say, 5.62 cm. In this measurement, there exists a maximum possible error of 0.01 cm. Thus we can say that, in the measure value "5" and "6" are certain digits and "2" is uncertain digit.

 

Hope it helps, Thank you for asking!
Thank you

dimensions of specific heat are L2 T-2 theta-1.how????

node.content:
Hello Anshita,

 

As you may know, definition of specific heat is: The heat required to raise the temperature of the unit mass of a given substance by a given amount (usually one degree). 

 

Which means :- Specific Heat = (Heat required)/(Temp)(Mass) = Energy/[M][K]

here K denotes temperature dimension and M denote mass of the substance for which specific heat is calculated. Hence the above formula.

Sir, I have few doubts in significants please kindly answer these questions:-

how many significant figures in:-

1.) 2(l+b)

2.) if I write 410 and 410meter then do both have 2 and 3 three significant figures respectively. And if we put measurement units like kg, meter, sec, gram etc, after extreme right zero(like 85200minute) without decimal then we have to count the zero as the significant figure.

3.) Add 6.75*10^3 cm and 4.52*10^2 cm with respect to significant figures.

  please explain these questions kindly because it messes my mind to0o much.

node.content:
Hello Rahul Kumar,

 

NOTE: Please ask precise and post only one question/doubt/explanation at a time.

1. 2(l+b) => here, values of l & b are not defined. So SIGNIFICANT Figures IN 2(l+b) WILL BE: Min(significant_number_in_l, significant_number_in_b) 

2. Here, you are quite right, when there are measurement like cm, m, kg etc All the zeros are counted which are right-to-Non-zero digit as significant figures.

3. Here, first make 1st as 6.75 x 10^3 cm & second as 0.452 x 10^3 cm => ans will be 7.17 x 10^3 cm... Or make 1st as 67.5 x 10^2 cm & second as 4.52 x 10^2 cm and ans will be 71.7 x 10^2 cm. Hence 4 Significant Digits. [Please revise the video if you are not sure how to do addition/subtraction on numbers and find out significant in result.]

doubts.content: Sir what is fermis rule!????

node.content:
Hello Sandesh Borse,

Note that the tagging you have provided to the doubt is not correct.

Fermions were first predicted in 1925 by the physicist Wolfgang Pauli, who was trying to figure out how to explain the atomic structure proposed in 1922 by Niels Bohr. Bohr had used experimental evidence to build an atomic model which contained electron shells, creating stable orbits for electrons to move around the atomic nucleus. Though this matched well with the evidence, there was no particular reason why this structure would be stable and that's the explanation that Pauli was trying to reach. He realized that if you assigned quantum numbers (later named quantum spin) to these electrons, then there seemed to be some sort of principle which meant that no two of the electrons could be in exactly the same state. This rule became known as the Pauli Exclusion Principle. Ref: url

In particle physics, a fermion is a type of particle that obeys the rules of Fermi-Dirac statistics, namely the Pauli Exclusion Principle. These fermions also have a quantum spin with contains a half-integer value, such as 1/2, -1/2, -3/2, and so on. 

Hope it helps.

doubts.content: sir i want to know [is hydogen bonding comes under vanderwaal forces or not]

node.content:
Hello Anup

Van der Waals forces include dipole-dipole forces, dipole-induced dipole forces, and London dispersion forces. 

Hydrogen bonding refers to the intermolecular dipole-dipole attraction between molecules that contain H−F, H−O, or H−N bonds.

So, because hydrogen bonding is a dipole-dipole force, it would be considered a van der Waals force as well.

thank you.

Hello Shushant,

 

Here are the solutions:

Q7 - Please follow the solution below the question. Here, alpha . z / k . theta will be dimensionless. And then you calculate dimension of alpha using concept of same dimension on both side of equation. Further, using dimension of alpha, you calculate dimension of beta by the equation of same dimension of both side of equal sign.

Rule of Dimensionality in Physics equation, Dimension of L.H.S. = Dimension of R.H.S.

 

Q13)

The number of significant figure in result will be :-  Least significant figure from values in right side, as here l = 12 cm, b = 6cm and h = 2.45 cm. 3 values are there l,b & h.

We know the formula for volume. It is multiplication of all these three values.

 

Since minimum least s.f. are in b which is 1, so in the result V = (l.b.h) = 12 x 6 x 2.45 = 176.4

But, here in this number 176.4 - Four significant digits are there... But as we saw above 1 is the least significant figure which is in b.

So, the answer will be 176.4 = 1.764 x 10^2 => 2 x 10^2. Now, we converted to scientific value then we rounded off the number to 1 (because in the final answer only 1 significant figure can be there. )

 

Q20 : Here you need to check dimension for both statement. Leave this question because question is not correctly uploaded.

 

Q26 : Permeability is measured in henries per metre (H·m−1 = J/(A2·m) = N·A−2).

 

Q47: As we know speed is change in distance in time t then, speed of light  = distance of sun from earth / time taken to travel light from sun to earth

        => c (speed of light) = d (distance) / t (time taken= 8 min 20 sec)

        => as speed of light is taken as 1 unit so, c = 3 x 10^8 m/s = 1 unit of length (as given in question)

        => now from formula d will be = c x t = 1 x (60*8+20) [because, unit of c is unit/second and unit of t is second, so we convert time into seconds]

        => hence d = 500 unit

 

Q51: Req  =R1 * R2R1 + R2, now delta Req  will be

 

delta(R1) * delta(R2)R1+R2 + delta(R1)  R1 + delta(R2)  R2, Where deltaR1 = 0.2 ohm & deltaR2 = 0.1 ohm

 

Percentage error will be (delta Req / Req ) * 100 .

sir, can u explain how to calculate the dimension of thermal conductivity?

node.content:
Hello Alrich,

Thermal conductivity has dimensions of Power/(length∗temperature)Power/(length∗temperature). Power is the rate of heat flow, (i.e.) energy flow in a given time. Length represents the thickness of the material the heat is flowing through, and temperature is the difference in temperature through which the heat is flowing.

In SI units, it is commonly expressed as Watts/(meter∗Kelvin)Watts/(meter∗Kelvin)

It expresses the rate at which heat is conducted through a unit thickness of a particular medium. That rate will vary linearly based on the temperature difference across the material, so it is expressed as a value per degree of temperature difference, thus Heat Rate per unit thickness per degree of temperature difference.

 

Hope you understood. Thank You, - NEETPrep

doubts.content: i dont understand in this ques  that how i calculate  z??? and how 2z=1?????

node.content:
Ans. (c)

Dimension of masss = [M]

Dimension of c = [LT^(-1)]

Dimension of G:-

G = gR^(2)/M     (using gravitational acceleration formula)

so [G] = [LT^(-2)]*[L^(2)]/[M]

    [G] = [M^(-1)L^(3)T^(-2)]

planck-einstein relation:-

E = hv

using this relation [h] = [ML^(2)T^(-1)]

Now assume [m] = [c]^(a)*[G]^(b)*[h]^(c)

by putting dimensions of each and comparing the powers of M,L and T

-b+c=1; a+3b+2c=0; -a-2b-c=0

by soving above equations

a= 1/2, b= -1/2, c= 1/2

so [m] = [c^(1/2)G^(-1/2)h^(1/2)]

node.content:
Ans. (b)

A solar day is a time it takes for the Earth to rotate about its axis so that the Sun appears in the same position in the sky

Mean solar day length = 24 hours

The sidereal day is the time it takes for the Earth to complete one rotation about its axis with respect to the 'fixed' stars

Sidereal day length = 23 hours 56 minutes 4.1 seconds

difference = 4 min (approximate)

Hello sir,

 

In ur explanation for SOLAR day I didn't understand the line "so that the Sun appears in the same position in the sky"

let's assume this time is noon. So the sun is directly above the earth. So after a complete rotation of the earth about its axis, the sun is not directly above the earth because the earth is moving on an elliptical path, not on a circular. So this time taken for the earth in a rotation is the sidereal day. So it is not noon now. For this time to be noon, the earth needs to rotate a little more. So, now it is noon. So the noon to noon is the solar day.

doubts.content:
The value of two resistors are (5.0 +- 0.2)kohm and (10.0 +- 0.1)kohm. What is the percentage error in the equivalent resistance when they are connected in parallel ?

a) 2%        b)5%        c)7%        d) 10%

node.content:
Ans. (c)

kiloohm = unit 

dR1, dR2 and dRs are the errors in the measurement of the respective resistors R1, R2 and Rs etc.

R1 = 5 unit, dR1 = 0.2 unit

R2 = 10 unit, dR2 = 0.1 unit

Equivalent resistance when resisors are connected in parallel

Rt = R1R2/(R1+R2) = R1R2/Rs 

where Rs = R1+R2

%error in R1 = (0.2/5)*100 = 4%

%error in R2 = (0.1/10)*100 = 1%

Rs = R1+R2 = 15 unit

dRs = dR1 + dR2 = 0.3 unit

%error in Rs = (0.3/15)*100 = 2%

%error in Rt = %error in R1 + %error in R2 + %error in Rs

                   = 4 + 1 + 2

                   = 7%

Hello Sushil,

The answer of LK Chandel is correct. You will learn more about these formulae( Resistance in Series, Resistance in Parallel in XII class) in Physics later.

Thnks,

Please ask us frankly using your words. Thank You - Naresh NEETPrep.com

doubts.content: In this question how to manage th e increase and decrease of pressure and volume respectivly . please make it clear sir

node.content:
Ans. (d)

Let us assume 

initial pressure = P(i), initial volume = V(i)

final pressure = P(f),  final volume = V(f)

Decrease in volume = 10%

so V(f) = V(i)- V(i)*(10/100) = (9/10)*V(i)

Ideal gas law: PV = nRT

given that temperature is constant during the process so 

PV = constant

P(i)V(i) = P(f)V(f)

P(f) = P(i)V(i)/V(f) = P(i)V(i)/((9/10)*V(i))

P(f) = (10/9)*P(i)

so percentage increase in the pressure of a given mass of a gas:-

((P(f)-P(i))/P(i))*100 = ((10/9)-1)*100 =100/9 

= 11.1%

Hello Sushil,

The answer of LK Chandel is correct. You will learn more about these formulae( PV=constant (Boyle's law)) in Physics later.

Thnks,

node.content:
Hi Ruchi,

As per question 140 of units and measurement:-

This formula is not taught until now but you will learn in future which is:-

Energy = (dimensionless constant)*k*T

k= Boltzmann constant 

T= Temperature

From here we can find out the dimension of k

[k] = ML^(2)T^(-2)ϴ^(-1)

In this question, the whole expression in the power of exponent or "e" should be dimensionless.

so [α][Z]/([k][ϴ]) = dimensionless

[α] = [k][ϴ]/[Z] = ML^(2)T^(-2)ϴ^(-1)*ϴ/[L]

[α] = MLT^(-2)

As given in the formula 

dimension of pressure = [α]/[β] = ML^(-1)T^(-2)

so [β] = [α]/(ML^(-1)T^(-2)) = (MLT^(-2))/(ML^(-1)T^(-2))

    [β] = M^(0)L^(2)T^(0)

node.content:
The eccentricity can be defined as the ratio of the semi-minor axis to the semimajor axis a:-

The eccentricity of ellipse = c/a 

where c2 = a2 - b2

c = distance between the center and any one of the focus point 

a = length of semi-major axis 

b = length of semi-minor axis
"The eccentricity can be defined as the ratio of the semi-minor axis to the semimajor axis a" is incorrect and written by mistake.

The resultant of two vectors P and Q is vector R. if Q is doubled ,the new resultant is perpendicular to P. then R equals to?

A particle moves in X-Y plane under the influence of a force such that its linear momentum is vector P(t)= A[i cos(kt)- j sin(kt)],where A and k are constat.The angle between the force and momentum is?

node.content:
Given:-

Linear momentum vector P = A[i cos(kt)- j sin(kt)]

By Newton's second law: (which may not be taught to you by now)

F =-dP/dt ; F: force, t: time

by substituting P in the above formula we get:-

so F = kA[i sinkt + j coskt ]

as you know d(sinkt)/dt = kcoskt and d(coskt)/dt = -ksinkt

Now P.F = kA^(2)(sinkt coskt - sinkt coskt) = 0

So P and F are perpendicular to each other.

So angle = 90º

How to determine diameter of a planet using "parallax angle"

node.content:
Parallax is defined as the apparent shift of a body with respect to a specific point on the background, with the shift of the eye.

To measure the distanc eof a planet or star WE observe it from two different positions (let) P1 and P2 seperated by distance P1P2 = d;

The angle P1 - Planet Position - P2 = theta, is mesasured with the help of an astronomical telescope called parallax angle or parallactic angle. Since the distance D of the planet or start is very large, hence.

theta = d/D or D = d/theta. This is the formulae to get diameter of planet or star using parallax angle method.

Hope it helps. Thanks Sanskar!

If you still have some doubts please ask under right doubt section immediately.

- Naresh, NEETPrep

doubts.content: How can we use mass spectrograph to measure masses of small atomic particles?

node.content:
That's a great question! 

Particle masses are measured in a great variety of ways. If they are big and heavy enough, you can put them on a scale. Subatomic particles have to be measured much more carefully than that. 

Typically, subatomic particle masses are determined by the relationship between their energy and their momentum. If a particle is not moving, its total energy is E=mc^2. If it is moving, then E^2=(mc^2)^2+(pc)^2, where p is the momentum and c is the speed of light. 

One way to measure the mass, say, of a proton, is to put it in a mass spectrometer. Accelerating it in a known electric field gives it an amount of kinetic energy proportional to its charge. Causing the proton to move in a circular path in a uniform, well-calibrated magnetic field allows the momentum to be measured quite precisely. 

Thank You, Sanskar!

In case you have any doubts please ask under doubt section of related chapters.

- Naresh, NEETPrep

node.content:
Ans. (d)

As we know |A×B| = |A||B|sinθ

and            |A.B| = |A||B|cosθ

|A×B|^2 + |A.B|^(2) =  (|A||B|sinθ)^(2) + (|A||B|cosθ)^(2)

                                 = |A|^(2)|B|^(2) (sin2 θ + cos2 θ)             (sin2 θ + cos2 θ = 1)

                                 = |A|^(2)|B|^(2)

node.content:
Answer (b)

A body is subjected to free fall from a certain height h under the gravitation effect which takes time t to reach the ground. 

so distance traversed by the body:-

h = (1/2)gt^(2) 

so g = 2h/t^(2)

Given %error in the measurement of distance dh = e1

              %error in the measurement of time dt = e2

so %error in the measurement of g = dh + 2dt = e1+2e2

so d(x^2+a^2)/dx = d(x^2)/dx + d(a^2)/dx = 2x + 0

= 2x

doubts.content:
sir, 

formation of depletion layer in this topic you saying that electrifield in the left direction in 6 layer so their is max .electrifield but i dont understand that how electrifield decreases and how 3rd layer electicfield in right direction??? 

one more question that is barrier potential graph and drift current??

node.content:
Hello Ruchi,

Here you can follow the video #3 | P N Junction & Depletion Region Formation of this chapter.

Following concepts must be clear to understand the concept of n-p junction & formation of Depletion layer.

1. Electric Field

2. Semiconductor Types

Potential Barrier: The electric potential of the n-side is higher than that of the p-side, the variation in potential is known as potential barrier at the junction which allow only a small amount of  diffusion (moving of electrons from the p-side to n-side).

Drift Current:- First let's say due to thermal collisions, occasionally a covalent bond is broken and the electron jumps to the conduction band. An electron-hole pair is thus created. ALSO, occasionally a conduction electron fills up a vacant bond so that an electron-pair is created in the depletion region, the electron is quickly pushed by the electric field towards the n-side and the hole towards the p-side.

There is almost no chance of recombination of a hole with an electron in the depletion region. As electron-hole pairs are continuously created in the depletion region, there is a regular flow of electrons towrads the n-side and of holes towards the p-side. This makes a current from the n-side to the p-side.

This current is callled the drift current.

You might try reading out the whole NCERT chapters First. Make a note and post to us if you have any doubt.

- Naresh, NEETPrep

doubts.content: Sir please explain the below given  question, i did not understand it by the hints given in the question.

node.content:
Hi Deeksha,

Assuming the rope to be massless and frictionless, the tension in the rope is same at all points and the acceleration of both masses are also the same.

In these type of questions, first of all, what you need to do is draw free body diagram and write the force balance equations.

Assuming m1>m2 then the direction of the acceleration is towards m1. 

Tension in the rope = T and acceleration of the masses = a

For mass m1:-

Force balance equation:-   m1g - T = m1a ........(1)

For mass m2:-

Force balance equation:-   T - m2g = m2a ........(2)

By adding both the equations (1) & (2):-

m1g - m2g = m1a + m2a

so a = (m1-m2)g/(m1+m2) 

now for the acceleration of the center of mass:-

Here we will take all accelerations with directions. So acceleration of the centre of mass:-

A =(m1a1 + m2a2)/(m1+m2)

A =(m1a-m2a)/(m1+m2) = (m1-m2)a/(m1+m2)    *\\ direction of the acceleration is downwords.

By substituting a:-

A=((m1-m2)/(m1+m2))^(2)g

So The correct answer is the option (c).
Thankyou sir

hello, here is your answer

Energy density / momentum density = c 
so momentum of emitted light = 0.1/c kg m per second each second. (c = speed of light - colour seems to be irrelevant). 

Force = rate of change of momentum. 
Force on glow-worm = 0.1/c newtons 

Acceleration = force / mass 
= 0.1/(c x 0.005) 

Speed = acceleration x time 
=0.1 x 10 x 365 x 24 x 60 x 60/(c x 0.005)

doubts.content: Please tell me the answer 0.6 is the mole fraction of solute or solvent ....I m confused in this

node.content:
The equation governing the change in the vapor pressure when you use a nonvolatile liquid or solid is just a special case of Raoult's Law, Ptot = PaXa + PbXb. Since the second component has a negligible vapor pressure (nonvolatile), Raoult's law reduces to

P = P0X
where P is the vapor pressure of the mixture, P0 is the vapor pressure of the pure solvent and X is the mole fraction of the solvent.
Mole fraction of solute = 0.2
so mole fraction of solvent = 0.8 
So
P-10 = 0.8(P)
So P= 10/0.2 = 50
 
In second case
50-20 = x.50
30/50= x
So mole fraction of solvent = 0.6
Is your doubt resolved, bhawna!

doubts.content:
If the velocity of light (c), gravitational constant (G) ,planks constant(h) are chosen as fundamental units then the dimension of mass in new system is

a)c^1/2 G^1/2 h^1/2

b) c ^1/2 G ^1/2 h ^-1/2

c) c^1/2G^-1/2 h^1/2

d) c^-1/2 G^1/2 h^1/2

Solution- 

[M]= [v]^x  [G]^y [h]^z

M= [LT^-1]^x [M^-1L^3T-2]^y [ML2T^-2]^z

M=L^x T^-1x  M^-y L^3y T^-2y M^z L^2z T ^-1z

After this step iam unable to solve this questions Sir please help me with this

node.content:
Hi Ayasha,

Here.... Next you will equate dimensions of Left Hand Side and Right Hand Side.

So, you have here,

Dimension of (M) in LHS is 1

Dimension of (M) in RHS is −y + z.

Similarly, Dimension of (L) in LHS is 0

and, Dimension of (L) in RHS is x + 3y + 2z

And, Dimension of (T) in LHS is 0 and in RHS is  −x  − 2y  − z

 

Hence,

We have three equations as Dimension of (LHS) for M, L, T = Dimension of (RHS)  for M, L, T

Now there are three variables and three equations.

−y + z = 1,  x + 3y + 2z = 0,  −x  − 2y  − z = 0

 Thank You.

For ns or np valence electrons

  1. electrons within same group shield 0.35, except the 1s which shield 0.30
  2. electrons within the n-1 group shield 0.85
  3. electrons within the n-2 or lower groups shield 1.00

doubts.content: The density of mercury is 13.6g/ml.The diameter of an atom of mercury assuming that each atom is occupying a cube of edge length equal to the diameter of the mercury atom is approximately?

node.content:
Hello Ambrosia 
here is your answer:-
Avogadro’s number = 6.023 * 1023
At. wt. of mercury(Hg) = 200
∵ In 1 g of Hg, the total number of atom
= 6.023 *1023/200 = 6.023 *1023/2 *102
= 3.0115 *1021 = 3.012 * 1021
∵ Density of Mercury (Hg) = 13.6 g/c.c.
∴ mass of 3.012 * 1021 atoms = 1/3.012 *1021
Now volume of 1 atom of mercury (Hg)
= 1/3.012 *1021 *13.6 c.c. = 103 *10/3012 *1021 * 136 c.c.
= 10-17/3012 *136 c.c. 10-17/409632 c.c. = 1000000 *10-23/409632 c.c.
= 2.44 *1023 c.c.
Since each mercury atom occupies a cube of edge length equal to its diameter, therefore,
Diameter of one Hg atom = (2.44 * 10-23)1/3 cm
= (24.4 * 10-24)1/3 cm.
= 2.905 * 10-8 cm ≡ 2.91 Å
 Thank you

doubts.content: Sir isse POAC se ni kr skte kya ?  Aur ye kaose hoga smjh ni aa rha

node.content:
More explanation below: 

As the volume occupied by gases only depends on number of moles of gases, the answer is related to number of moles of gases produced. 

Since, no temperature and pressure is given, one can assume NTP. 

At NTP, the reaction produces Phosphorous(Solid) and Hydrogen(gas). Looking at the balanced equation above, 2 moles of PH3 gas would give 3 moles of H2 gas. 

Therefore, there is 50% increase in number of gaseous molecules after reaction. (2 to 3 moles)

As the volume depends on number of moles, the increased volume is also 50% more than original volume. 

Increase in volume = Original Volume * 50 % = 100 ml * 50% = 50ml

New Volume = Original Volume + Increase in Volume = (100 + 50) ml = 150 ml

hello Sourabh

here is your answer

Given that, formula of first oxide = M3O4
Let mass of the metal = x
% of metal in M3O4 = (3x/ 3x+64) *100
but as given % age = (100-27.6) = 72.4 %
so, (3x/ 3x+64)*100 = 72.4
or x = 56.
in 2nd oxide,
oxygen = 30%....so metal = 70%
so, the ratio is
M : O
70/56 : 30/16
1.25 : 1.875
2 : 3
so, 2nd oxide is M2O3
thank you.

doubts.content: plz explain this answer

node.content:
Hello Akshay

here is your answer.

Let CO = x moles So, CO2= 1-x moles. Now 2NaOH + CO2 ----> Na2CO3 + H2O
2 moles NaOH react with 1 mole CO2
So, 20g NaOH = 0.5 Mole NaOH will react with 1/4 = 0.25 mole CO2 = 1-x moles So, x=0.75moles ie moles of CO = 0.75 moles. 
Now On oxidation CO + 1/2O2 -----> CO2
0.75------------------> CO2(0.75moles)
Total Moles of CO2 = 0.25 + 0.75 = 1mole
1 mole CO2 will react with 2 moles NaOH ie 40 x 2 = 80g.

thank you.

doubts.content: SIR PLEASE SOLVE THIS QUESTION BY EQUIVALENT CONCEPT.I GOT Y ANSWER AS 1 MOLE BY SOLVING THIS BY EQUIVALENT CONCEPT

node.content:
Hello Akshay

Equivalent concept is not apllicable everywhere. So you can do this problem in unitery method also discussed below.

Let the acid be HCL
Reaction; Mg+2HCL→MgCl2+H2
This shows that 1 mole of Mg(atomic mass=24g)will produce 1 mole of H2(Molar mass=2g)

doubts.content: sir,why the spring force is conservative? i mean work done by a conservative force in a closed path is zero.but spring force opposes the motion like frictional force so how it has zero work done in a closed path?

node.content:
It is a conservative force. By definition of conservative forces,

  1. The work done on an object in a closed loop (same initial and final position) is 0
    1. This is a consequence from the first point, and also is true for the spring force

In conclusion, the spring force (of an ideal spring) is a conservative force

doubts.content: sir,you better teach in hindi than english....so kindly teach in hindi only.

The First ionisational enthalpies of NA,Mg,Al,Si are in the order

a. Na<Mg<al>Si

b. na<mg>al<si

c. na<mg<al<si

d. na>mg>al<si

node.content:
Hello Gaurav kumar

Answer: Na < Mg > Al < Si
The electronic configurations are as follows: 11Na(3s)1,12Mg(3s)2,13Al(3s)2(3p)1,14Si(3s)2(3p)211Na(3s)1,12Mg(3s)2,13Al(3s)2(3p)1,14Si(3s)2(3p)2
The ionization energy of Mg will be larger than that of Na due to fully filled configuration (3s)2(3s)2
The ionization of Al will be smaller than that of Mg due to one electron extra than the stable configuration but smaller than Si due to increase in effective nuclear charge of Si.
⇒ Na < Mg > Al < Si
thank you.

doubts.content: SIR WILL THE NAMING CHANGE ACCORDING TO ALPHABETICAL ORDER IF I USE oxo INSTEAD OF keto OR VICE VERSA

node.content:
Hello Tamanna 

for a - CHO aldehyde group we use secondary prefix as formyl,oxo,aldo and secondary sufix as al

for -CO- ketone group we use secondary prefix as Oxo and secondary suffix as one.

yahh one thing more

in case of - CHO , two diffrent prefixes are used Aldo or formyl and oxo. secondary priffix formul or aldo is used when - CHO is directly attached to main chain but seconadry prefix Oxo is used in case when alkyl group is attached to main skelton .

also secondary preffix oxo is used for aldehyde as well as keetons when CO is part of main or side skelton and the carbon of CO is counted in skelton.

hope this will help you

thank you.
